CatDescriptText: Partial article for related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 4, 1951, pg. 22, reads: "WHOD Opens Studio Dee, Mary Dee Program Has 150,000 Listeners Daily - Hundreds of well-wishers gathered at the new Studio Dee, corner of Centre Avenue and Herron, Wednesday afternoon to help celebrate the opening of this new branch of the popular Station WHOD in Homestead - the station from which the popular Mary Dee's 'Moving Round' program emanates. Manager Roy Ferree, beaming with pride, told the press the opening of Studio Dee was not only a tribute to Mary, but to her thousands of listeners in Western Pennsylvania and West Virginia, who since Aug. 1, 1948, have given WHOD and 'Moving Round' loyal support.  Has Grown with Station - The opening of Studio Dee also marks the third anniversary of WHOD - a station which started out with a democratic policy, and despite many bigoted and feeble protest from un-American sources, has maintained that same policy.  A roomful of floral tributes, plus hundreds of telegrams, letters, and cards attested to the popularity of the little brown-skinned girl, who in 1948, fresh out of the Si Mann Radio School, launched out with a fifteen-minute disc-jockey program six days a weeks, that has since grown to two hours each weekday, which a ten-minute Courier Newscast and an hour program of spiritual music each Sunday evening...."
TitMainTitle: Man posed next to Fort Pitt beer display in room full of gladiolus for Studio Dee opening party at WHOD Radio Station
